title: Introduction to oneMeanTest
text: oneMeanTest package provides tools performing one-sample t-test population mean variance unknown, along descriptive statistics, assumption checks, bootstrap-based inference, power analysis, informative plots. vignette shows complete analysis workflow using simulated data mimics real application.

title: Introduction to oneMeanTest
text: library(oneMeanTest) set.seed(123)

title: Introduction to oneMeanTest
text: Suppose measure numeric outcome (e.g., exam scores, weights, waiting times) n=30n = 30 individuals, want test whether population mean equals hypothesized value μ0=5\mu_0 = 5. simulate dataset: x <- rnorm(30, mean = 5, sd = 2) head(x) length(x) can replace simulated data dataset using package practice.

title: Introduction to oneMeanTest
text: running hypothesis test, examine basic descriptive statistics. ds <- descriptive_stats(x, digits = NULL) ds output includes sample size, mean, median, standard deviation, standard error, variance, range, quartiles, IQR.

title: Introduction to oneMeanTest
text: now perform one-sample t-test H0:μ=5vs.Ha:μ≠5. H_0: \mu = 5 \quad \text{vs.} \quad H_a: \mu \neq 5. res <- one_mean_test( x, mu0 = 5, alternative = “two.sided”, alpha = 0.05, conf.level = 0.95, check_assumptions = TRUE ) res printed result shows: t statistic degrees freedom p-value confidence interval mean sample mean decision reject fail reject H0H_0 plain-language interpretation.

title: Introduction to oneMeanTest
text: one-sample t-test assumes data approximately normally distributed (sample size large enough central limit theorem apply). check_assumptions() function, called inside one_mean_test() check_assumptions = TRUE, provides basic assessment: assump <- check_assumptions(x, alpha = 0.05, verbose = FALSE) assump Interpret results decide whether normality assumption reasonable.

title: Introduction to oneMeanTest
text: plot() method oneMeanTest objects provides several useful visualizations. First, t-distribution observed t statistic critical values: plot(res, = “t”) Next, confidence interval plot mean: plot(res, = “ci”) store raw data result object, can also draw histogram, boxplot, normal Q-Q plot: attr(res, “data”) <- x plot(res, = “hist”) plot(res, = “box”) plot(res, = “qq”) plots can used directly screenshots presentation.

title: Introduction to oneMeanTest
text: bootstrap_ttest() function implements simple non-parametric bootstrap procedure one-sample mean. boot_res <- bootstrap_ttest( x, mu0 = 5, nboot = 500, conf.level = 0.95, alternative = “two.sided”, seed = 123 ) boot_res can compare bootstrap confidence interval p-value classical t-test results part discussion.

title: Introduction to oneMeanTest
text: Finally, power_analysis_one_mean() wraps stats::power.t.test() one-sample t-tests. example, compute power detecting true difference 1 unit n=30n = 30, sd=2sd = 2, α=0.05\alpha = 0.05: p_res <- power_analysis_one_mean( n = 30, delta = 1, sd = 2, sig.level = 0.05, power = NULL, alternative = “two.sided” ) p_res find required sample size 80% power: n_res <- power_analysis_one_mean( n = NULL, delta = 1, sd = 2, sig.level = 0.05, power = 0.8, alternative = “two.sided” ) n_res

title: Introduction to oneMeanTest
text: vignette, : simulated numeric dataset; computed descriptive statistics; performed one-sample t-test using one_mean_test(); checked assumptions, created informative plots, compared bootstrap-based inference; explored power analysis using power_analysis_one_mean(). can adapt workflow data analyze single population mean unknown variance create materials STAT 181 presentation.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Name. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Name Y (2025). oneMeanTest: One-Sample T-Test Population Mean Unknown Variance. R package version 0.1.0.
code: @Manual{,   title = {oneMeanTest: One-Sample T-Test for Population Mean with Unknown Variance},   author = {Your Name},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.1.0}, }

what: One-Sample T-Test for Population Mean with Unknown Variance
title: One-Sample T-Test for Population Mean with Unknown Variance
text: R package performing one-sample t-test population mean variance unknown, developed STAT 181 (Statistical Computing) project Institute Statistics, Diliman.

title: One-Sample T-Test for Population Mean with Unknown Variance
text: can install development version GitHub: install.packages(“devtools”) # needed devtools::install_github(“KingSSIBAL/oneMeantTest”) load package: library(oneMeanTest)

title: One-Sample T-Test for Population Mean with Unknown Variance
text: one_mean_test() Perform one-sample t-test population mean unknown variance. Returns: test statistic degrees freedom p-value confidence interval mean decision reject fail reject (H_0) plain-language interpretation optional assumption checks descriptive_stats() Basic descriptive statistics (n, mean, median, sd, se, variance, quantiles, IQR) numeric sample. check_assumptions() Check normality basic assumptions using one-sample t-test. bootstrap_ttest() Bootstrap-based one-sample t-test: bootstrap distribution t-statistic, bootstrap p-value, percentile CI mean. power_analysis_one_mean() Wrapper around stats::power.t.test() one-sample t-test power analysis (solve power required sample size). plot() methods objects class oneMeanTest oneMeanTest_bootstrap Visualizations including: t-distribution observed statistic critical region histogram boxplot data (_0) sample mean normal Q-Q plot confidence interval plot mean

title: One-Sample T-Test for Population Mean with Unknown Variance
text: library(oneMeanTest) set.seed(123) x <- rnorm(30, mean = 5, sd = 2) res <- one_mean_test( x, mu0 = 5, alternative = “two.sided”, alpha = 0.05, conf.level = 0.95, check_assumptions = TRUE ) res # print main results plot(res, “t”) # t-distribution test statistic plot(res, “ci”) # confidence interval mean

title: One-Sample T-Test for Population Mean with Unknown Variance
text: Use oneMeanTest : one numeric sample (independent observations). want test hypothesis single population mean unknown variance. population approximately normal (sample size moderately large). want classical t-test results, optionally bootstrap-based inference power analysis. package created STAT 181, 1st Semester 2025–2026, educational tool understanding one-sample t-test related concepts.

title: Bootstrap one-sample t-test — bootstrap_ttest
text: Perform simple non-parametric bootstrap procedure one-sample t-test population mean unknown variance.

title: Bootstrap one-sample t-test — bootstrap_ttest
code: bootstrap_ttest(   x,   mu0 = 0,   nboot = 1000,   conf.level = 0.95,   alternative = c("two.sided", "less", "greater"),   seed = NULL )

title: Bootstrap one-sample t-test — bootstrap_ttest
text: x Numeric vector observations. mu0 Hypothesized population mean null hypothesis. nboot Number bootstrap resamples (integer, usually least 100). conf.level Confidence level bootstrap confidence interval. alternative Character string specifying alternative hypothesis, one "two.sided", "less", "greater". seed Optional integer seed reproducibility.

title: Bootstrap one-sample t-test — bootstrap_ttest
text: list class "oneMeanTest_bootstrap" components: t.obs Observed t-statistic. t.boot Numeric vector bootstrap t-statistics. mean.obs Observed sample mean. mean.boot Numeric vector bootstrap means. conf.int Bootstrap percentile confidence interval mean (numeric vector length 2 attribute conf.level). p.value Bootstrap p-value. nboot Number bootstrap resamples. mu0 Hypothesized mean. alternative Alternative hypothesis used. call matched function call.

title: Bootstrap one-sample t-test — bootstrap_ttest
text: function resamples observed data replacement, computes t-statistic bootstrap sample, uses empirical distribution statistics obtain bootstrap p-value percentile confidence interval mean. useful illustrating resampling-based inference comparing classical t-test results bootstrap results.

title: Bootstrap one-sample t-test — bootstrap_ttest
code: set.seed(123) x <- rnorm(30, mean = 5, sd = 2)  boot_res <- bootstrap_ttest(   x,   mu0 = 5,   nboot = 500,   conf.level = 0.95,   alternative = "two.sided",   seed = 123 ) boot_res #> Bootstrap one-sample t-test #>  #> Call: #> bootstrap_ttest(x = x, mu0 = 5, nboot = 500, conf.level = 0.95,  #>     alternative = "two.sided", seed = 123) #>  #> Observed t-statistic: -0.2630 #> Bootstrap p-value  : 0.82 #> 95.0000% bootstrap CI for the mean: #>   [4.1919, 5.5519] #> Number of resamples: 500

what: Assumption checks for one-sample t-test — check_assumptions
title: Assumption checks for one-sample t-test — check_assumptions
text: Check normality outliers numeric sample, typically required one-sample t-test population mean unknown variance.

title: Assumption checks for one-sample t-test — check_assumptions
code: check_assumptions(x, alpha = 0.05, verbose = TRUE)

title: Assumption checks for one-sample t-test — check_assumptions
text: x numeric vector observations. alpha Significance level Shapiro–Wilk normality test. verbose Logical; TRUE, prints short textual summary results console.

title: Assumption checks for one-sample t-test — check_assumptions
text: list class "oneMeanTest_assumptions" components: shapiro List W statistic, p-value, alpha, logical flag normal indicating normality acceptable (NA test run). outliers Numeric vector detected outliers (possibly empty). n Sample size removing NA values. normal Logical flag indicating normality acceptable (TRUE / FALSE), FALSE Shapiro–Wilk test rejects chosen alpha. message Textual summary diagnostics.

title: Assumption checks for one-sample t-test — check_assumptions
text: function performs Shapiro–Wilk normality test (sample size 3 5000) detects outliers using 1.5*IQR rule. used inside one_mean_test check_assumptions = TRUE.

title: Assumption checks for one-sample t-test — check_assumptions
code: set.seed(123) x <- rnorm(30, mean = 5, sd = 2)  # Verbose output check_assumptions(x, alpha = 0.05, verbose = TRUE) #> Normality appears acceptable based on the Shapiro-Wilk test. No outliers detected by the 1.5*IQR rule.  #> $shapiro #> $shapiro$W #> [1] 0.9789351 #>  #> $shapiro$p.value #> [1] 0.7965839 #>  #> $shapiro$alpha #> [1] 0.05 #>  #> $shapiro$normal #> [1] TRUE #>  #>  #> $outliers #> numeric(0) #>  #> $n #> [1] 30 #>  #> $normal #> [1] TRUE #>  #> $message #> [1] "Normality appears acceptable based on the Shapiro-Wilk test. No outliers detected by the 1.5*IQR rule." #>  #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "oneMeanTest_assumptions"  # Silent output (used internally by one_mean_test) a_res <- check_assumptions(x, alpha = 0.05, verbose = FALSE) a_res #> $shapiro #> $shapiro$W #> [1] 0.9789351 #>  #> $shapiro$p.value #> [1] 0.7965839 #>  #> $shapiro$alpha #> [1] 0.05 #>  #> $shapiro$normal #> [1] TRUE #>  #>  #> $outliers #> numeric(0) #>  #> $n #> [1] 30 #>  #> $normal #> [1] TRUE #>  #> $message #> [1] "Normality appears acceptable based on the Shapiro-Wilk test. No outliers detected by the 1.5*IQR rule." #>  #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "oneMeanTest_assumptions"

what: Descriptive statistics for a numeric sample — descriptive_stats
title: Descriptive statistics for a numeric sample — descriptive_stats
text: Compute basic descriptive statistics numeric vector, including sample size, mean, median, standard deviation, variance, standard error, quartiles, range, interquartile range (IQR).

title: Descriptive statistics for a numeric sample — descriptive_stats
code: descriptive_stats(x, digits = 3)

title: Descriptive statistics for a numeric sample — descriptive_stats
text: x numeric vector observations. digits Optional integer; number digits round printed output. NULL, rounding applied.

title: Descriptive statistics for a numeric sample — descriptive_stats
text: data frame one row summary statistics: n: sample size (number non-missing observations). mean: sample mean. median: sample median. sd: sample standard deviation. variance: sample variance. se: standard error mean. min, q1, q3, max: minimum, first quartile, third quartile, maximum. iqr: interquartile range (q3 - q1).

title: Descriptive statistics for a numeric sample — descriptive_stats
text: function intended numeric data measurements scores, typically type data used one-sample t-test.

title: Descriptive statistics for a numeric sample — descriptive_stats
code: x <- c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5) descriptive_stats(x) #>  n mean median    sd variance    se min q1 q3 max iqr #>  5    3      3 1.581      2.5 0.707   1  2  4   5   2  # Without rounding descriptive_stats(x, digits = NULL) #>  n mean median       sd variance        se min q1 q3 max iqr #>  5    3      3 1.581139      2.5 0.7071068   1  2  4   5   2

title: Example analysis pipeline — example_one_mean_pipeline
text: helper shows simple workflow: generate data, run one-sample t-test, return test object. can used demonstrations vignettes.

title: Example analysis pipeline — example_one_mean_pipeline
code: example_one_mean_pipeline(   n = 30,   true_mean = 80,   sd = 10,   mu0 = 75,   seed = NULL )

title: Example analysis pipeline — example_one_mean_pipeline
text: n Sample size. true_mean True mean data generation. sd True standard deviation data generation. mu0 Hypothesized mean. seed Optional integer seed.

title: Example analysis pipeline — example_one_mean_pipeline
text: object class "oneMeanTest".

title: Format T-test Report — format_ttest_report
text: Formats one-sample t-test results according STAT 181 project guidelines. Generates professional, human-readable report essential components including descriptive statistics, hypotheses, test statistics, critical values, p-value, confidence interval, decision, interpretation.

title: Format T-test Report — format_ttest_report
code: format_ttest_report(test_result, include_sections = c("all"))

title: Format T-test Report — format_ttest_report
text: test_result Object class oneMeanTest one_mean_test() include_sections Character vector sections include: "descriptives", "hypotheses", "test_statistic", "critical_value", "p_value", "ci", "conclusion". Default "" includes everything.

title: Format T-test Report — format_ttest_report
text: formatted report character string can printed cat()

title: Format T-test Report — format_ttest_report

code: generate_example_scores(n = 30, mean = 80, sd = 10, seed = NULL)

title: Generate example test score data — generate_example_scores
text: n Sample size. mean True mean used simulation. sd True standard deviation used simulation. seed Optional integer seed reproducibility.

title: Generate example test score data — generate_example_scores
text: numeric vector length n.

code: generate_example_weights(n = 30, mean = 500, sd = 5, seed = NULL)

title: oneMeanTest: One-sample t-test package — oneMeanTest
text: oneMeanTest package provides functions perform one-sample t-test population mean population variance unknown, along assumption checks, descriptive statistics, basic plotting utilities educational use.

title: oneMeanTest: One-sample t-test package — oneMeanTest
text: Maintainer: Name .email@example.com

what: One-sample t-test for a population mean (unknown variance) — one_mean_test
title: One-sample t-test for a population mean (unknown variance) — one_mean_test
text: Perform one-sample t-test population mean population variance unknown, using Student's t-distribution. function returns usual test statistic, p-value, confidence interval, plain-language interpretation, can optionally run assumption checks.

title: One-sample t-test for a population mean (unknown variance) — one_mean_test
code: one_mean_test(   x,   mu0 = 0,   alternative = c("two.sided", "less", "greater"),   alpha = 0.05,   conf.level = 0.95,   check_assumptions = TRUE )

title: One-sample t-test for a population mean (unknown variance) — one_mean_test
text: x numeric vector observations. mu0 hypothesized population mean null hypothesis. alternative Character string specifying alternative hypothesis, one "two.sided", "less", "greater". alpha Significance level used hypothesis decision. conf.level Confidence level confidence interval. check_assumptions Logical; TRUE, performs assumption checks via check_assumptions stores result returned object.

title: One-sample t-test for a population mean (unknown variance) — one_mean_test
text: object class "oneMeanTest" containing: statistic Named numeric vector t statistic. parameter Named numeric vector degrees freedom. p.value P-value test. conf.int Numeric vector confidence interval mean, attribute conf.level. estimate Named numeric vector sample mean. null.value Named numeric vector hypothesized mean (mu0). alternative Character string alternative hypothesis. method Description method used. data.name Character string name data vector. sample.stats List n, mean, sd, se. alpha Significance level used. assumptions Result check_assumptions() NULL. decision Character string: "reject H0" "fail reject H0". interpretation Plain-language interpretation result.

title: One-sample t-test for a population mean (unknown variance) — one_mean_test

what: Plot methods for one-sample mean test objects — plot.oneMeanTest
title: Plot methods for one-sample mean test objects — plot.oneMeanTest
text: Plot methods objects class "oneMeanTest" produced one_mean_test. Different values produce different visualizations:

title: Plot methods for one-sample mean test objects — plot.oneMeanTest
code: # S3 method for class 'oneMeanTest' plot(x, which = c("t", "hist", "qq", "box", "ci"), ...)

title: Plot methods for one-sample mean test objects — plot.oneMeanTest
text: x object class "oneMeanTest". Character string specifying plot draw. One "t", "hist", "qq", "box", "ci". ... Additional arguments passed underlying graphics functions (currently unused).

title: Plot methods for one-sample mean test objects — plot.oneMeanTest
text: Invisibly returns x producing plot.

title: Plot methods for one-sample mean test objects — plot.oneMeanTest
text: "t": t-distribution observed test statistic critical values chosen alpha. "hist": histogram data vertical lines sample mean hypothesized mean mu0. "qq": normal Q-Q plot data reference line. "box": boxplot data vertical line mu0. "ci": confidence interval plot mean. "hist", "qq", "box", raw data must stored object via attr(x, "data") <- your_data.

title: Plot methods for one-sample mean test objects — plot.oneMeanTest
code: set.seed(123) x <- rnorm(30, mean = 5, sd = 2) res <- one_mean_test(x, mu0 = 5, check_assumptions = FALSE) attr(res, "data") <- x  plot(res, which = "t")  plot(res, which = "ci")  plot(res, which = "hist")  plot(res, which = "qq")  plot(res, which = "box")

what: Power analysis for one-sample t-test — power_analysis_one_mean
title: Power analysis for one-sample t-test — power_analysis_one_mean
text: Wrapper around power.t.test one-sample t-test population mean unknown variance.

title: Power analysis for one-sample t-test — power_analysis_one_mean
code: power_analysis_one_mean(   n = NULL,   delta = NULL,   sd = 1,   sig.level = 0.05,   power = NULL,   alternative = c("two.sided", "one.sided") )

title: Power analysis for one-sample t-test — power_analysis_one_mean
text: n Sample size (NULL computed). delta True difference means (\(\mu - \mu_0\)). sd Standard deviation (estimated assumed). sig.level Significance level (alpha). power Desired power (NULL computed). alternative Character string specifying alternative hypothesis, either "two.sided" "one.sided".

title: Power analysis for one-sample t-test — power_analysis_one_mean
text: object class "power.htest" returned power.t.test type = "one.sample".

title: Power analysis for one-sample t-test — power_analysis_one_mean
text: must supply exactly two three arguments n, delta, power; third computed, power.t.test. function useful : computing power one-sample t-test given sample size, effect size (delta), significance level; computing required sample size achieve desired power.

title: Power analysis for one-sample t-test — power_analysis_one_mean
code: # Power for n = 30, true difference = 1, sd = 2 p_res <- power_analysis_one_mean(   n = 30,   delta = 1,   sd = 2,   sig.level = 0.05,   power = NULL,   alternative = "two.sided" ) p_res #>  #>      One-sample t test power calculation  #>  #>               n = 30 #>           delta = 1 #>              sd = 2 #>       sig.level = 0.05 #>           power = 0.7539627 #>     alternative = two.sided #>   # Required n for 80% power n_res <- power_analysis_one_mean(   n = NULL,   delta = 1,   sd = 2,   sig.level = 0.05,   power = 0.8,   alternative = "two.sided" ) n_res #>  #>      One-sample t test power calculation  #>  #>               n = 33.3672 #>           delta = 1 #>              sd = 2 #>       sig.level = 0.05 #>           power = 0.8 #>     alternative = two.sided #>
